name: Manjushri
title: Manjushri - Bodhisattva of Transcendent Wisdom
description: Manjushri (Sanskrit: 'Gentle Glory') embodies the prajna (transcendent wisdom) of all Buddhas. He wields the flaming sword of discriminating awareness that cuts through ignorance, delusion, and dualistic thinking, revealing the empty nature of all phenomena.
summary: The Bodhisattva of Wisdom who wields the flaming sword to cut through ignorance. Patron of scholars, teachers, and all who seek understanding of ultimate truth.

standardForm.appearance: Youthful prince (kumara) of sixteen years, representing eternal freshness of wisdom
standardForm.ornaments: Crown, earrings, necklaces, armlets, flowing silk garments of a bodhisattva

flamingSword.name: Prajna Khadga
symbolism: Cuts through the darkness of ignorance (avidya)
Severs the root of clinging to a permanent self
Slices through dualistic thinking and conceptual elaboration
Reveals the emptiness (shunyata) of all phenomena
Flames represent purifying fire that burns away mental obscurations

prajnaparamitaSutra.location: Left hand, supported on blue lotus stem
symbolism: Wisdom that has gone beyond to the other shore (enlightenment)
Sutras teaching emptiness as ultimate nature of reality
Union of scripture (written wisdom) and realization (living wisdom)
Lotus blooms in mud (samsara) yet remains unstained
Mastery over fear and timidity in teaching truth
King of beasts representing wisdom as king of virtues
Freedom from timidity that prevents speaking difficult truths

multiArmedForms.name: Manjuvajra
multiArmedForms.description: Holding vajra and bell - union of wisdom and method

multiArmedForms.name: Arapacana Manjushri
multiArmedForms.description: Five syllables representing the five wisdoms

multiArmedForms.name: Yamantaka
multiArmedForms.description: Wrathful form - Slayer of the Lord of Death, defeating ignorance-as-death

origin.description: According to Manjushri Mulakalpa, in ancient times Manjushri was a fully enlightened Buddha named Lampadhara Tathagata in a pure land to the east.
origin.vow: Out of great compassion, he voluntarily relinquished his Buddha status to become a bodhisattva, taking a subordinate position to better serve sentient beings by appearing as a student asking questions of other Buddhas.

wisdomNature.prajna: Not ordinary knowledge or intelligence but transcendent wisdom - direct, non-conceptual insight into the ultimate nature of reality
aspects: Understanding of Emptiness (Shunyata) - all phenomena lack inherent existence
Discriminating Wisdom - distinguishing truth from delusion
Analytical Insight - understanding cause and effect, skandhas, dharmas
Direct Realization - not just intellectual understanding but embodied awakening

swordAndBook.sword: Negative Wisdom - cuts away false views, destroys ignorance, negates clinging. Via negativa saying 'not this, not that'
swordAndBook.sutra: Positive Wisdom - offers the path, provides guidance, teaches skillful means. Via affirmativa pointing to enlightenment

mantra.text: Om A Ra Pa Ca Na Dhih
syllableMeanings: OM - vajra body, speech, and mind of all Buddhas
A - unoriginated nature of all phenomena (primordial purity)
RA - free from dust, purifying conceptual stains
PA - beyond paramita, transcending ordinary perfections
CA - no movement in samsara, beyond birth-death cycle
DHIH - seed syllable of Manjushri, representing prajna itself

practices: Manjushri Sadhana - visualization practice with mantra recitation
Analytical Meditation - using logic to investigate nature of self and phenomena
Study Practice - deep study of Prajnaparamita and Madhyamaka texts
Debate - rigorous logical debate to sharpen discriminating wisdom
devotionalPractices: Invoking Manjushri before study or teaching sessions
Pilgrimage to Mount Wutai (Wu Tai Shan) in China
Offering lights to represent dispelling darkness of ignorance
Reciting texts of the Prajnaparamita cycle
temples: Mount Wutai (Wu Tai Shan), China - sacred mountain of Manjushri
Numerous temples throughout Tibet, Nepal, and East Asia

vimalakirtisUtra.content: The Buddha said to Manjushri: 'You go to Vimalakirti to inquire about his illness.' Manjushri replied: 'World-Honored One, it is difficult to match him in discussion. He has penetrated deeply into the reality of all dharmas.'
vimalakirtisUtra.significance: Shows Manjushri's supreme wisdom and fearlessness in discourse

vimalakirtisUtra.content: Manjushri said: 'All dharmas have no speech, no description, no demonstration, and no cognition. They transcend all questions and answers. That is the entrance to non-duality.' Vimalakirti remained silent. Manjushri exclaimed: 'Excellent! No words, no speech - that is truly the entrance to non-duality!'

lotusSutra.content: Manjushri was sitting on a thousand-petaled lotus flower, having come from the palace of Sagara the Dragon King, where he had been expounding the Lotus Sutra. The daughter of the Dragon King, only eight years old, attained Buddhahood instantly.
lotusSutra.significance: Manjushri as teacher even in the dragon realm

prajnaparamita.content: Manjushri said: 'World-Honored One, what is the bodhisattva's perfection of wisdom?' The Buddha replied: 'When a bodhisattva courses in perfect wisdom, he does not see form as form... All dharmas are empty of own-nature.'
prajnaparamita.significance: Manjushri as questioner eliciting wisdom teachings

manjushriTexts.content: In ancient times, Manjushri was a fully enlightened Buddha named Lampadhara Tathagata. Out of great compassion, he voluntarily relinquished his Buddha status to become a bodhisattva.
Homage to Manjushri, the youthful! Holder of the sword of wisdom that cuts through the darkness of delusion! All Buddhas' father, mother of all bodhisattvas!

tibetanSources.author: Jamyang Shepa
tibetanSources.content: Manjushri is the embodiment of the wisdom of all Buddhas of past, present, and future. Without wisdom, compassion becomes mere sentimentality.

avatamsakaSutra.content: Manjushri told Sudhana: 'Do not think I am your only teacher. Seek out all who embody virtue, learn from bodhisattvas in all walks of life.' This demonstrates Manjushri's wisdom: the wise teacher knows he must send the student forth rather than creating dependency.

extendedContent.sacredMountain: Mount Wutai (Wu Tai Shan) in Shanxi Province, China - one of the Four Sacred Buddhist Mountains
extendedContent.wrathfulForm: Yamantaka (Slayer of Death) - terrifying form with buffalo head, conquering Yama (death) and ego-clinging

relationship.avalokiteshvara: Compassion paired with wisdom - complementary bodhisattvas
